alternatives.transcript: there are several Technologies today which can improve the quality of the indoor environment and accommodate smoking at the same time in the instance of accommodating smoking in the workplace largely what you want to do is to increase the dilution of the are in the workplace and there are several Technologies today that can increase the amount of outdoor air you can bring into a building without sacrificing energy conservation goals in particular some air to air heat exchangers have been developed which allow things

things for example as the preservation of humidity levels so that you don't introduce high humidity levels from outside with the outdoor air that you're bringing in this is especially important in hot and humid climates such as in the southeast United States and many places around the world this technology has evolved over the last five years or so so that many commercial models are available on small scales all the way up to large scales so that almost any building can be retrofitted with that kind of Technology

one great feature of these Technologies today is that many improvements have resulted in models that can be retrofitted to existing buildings and particularly on to them so called package units where existing are Handling Systems simply have these units attached to them and they take the return air from the unit use that to precondition the air that enters the unit and you get outdoor Air instead of recirculated air in the same system very Compact and very spacious
space conscious items have been developed and so these devices can now be readily retrofit into existing buildings

I really believe that with good ventilation acceptable indoor air quality can be achieved throughout a facility in the context of allowing discretionary smoking the really important question is do you take care with the ventilation system and make sure that you have adequate dilution and then if you do choose to have smoking and non-smoking areas do you properly set those up so that the non-smoking area and smoking area don't overlap and you avoid the issues of
drifting from where the smokers are smoking to where non-smokers choose to be

there are a range of options you can choose to accommodate smokers and non-smokers and building some buildings have restricted smoking in most general areas and have installed things like smoking Lounge has the building and we're sitting in today has a smoking lounge and it works very very effectively and there are several smoking areas available for those who choose to smoke in this building in other buildings discretionary smoking is allowed and they're acceptable indoor air quality can be achieved as long as outdoor air ventilation rates

it's are maintained at high enough levels good filtration also helps it helps reduce the concentration of particulates that might otherwise be recycled into the space and the third option of course is the separation of smoking and non-smoking areas within a work area that is a little bit trickier and it takes some more planning and forethought but can be done very effectively what you do and that condition is to use air pressure relationships basically you supply more air into the non-smoking areas which then

blows the air into the into the smoking areas from the smoking areas you exhaust the air so that the smoke is contained in the smoking area and air flows from the non-smoking area into the smoking area at that point very little drift if in fact no drift typically occurs if you've designed it correctly

indoor air quality is determined by a number of factors in an indoor environment some of those are very simple and they've lasted a long time we know about them those are things like thermal conditions if people to are too hot or too cold typically they also complain about the quality of the indoor air but let's go beyond that there are many factors that determine very real indoor air quality those are the constituents of the indoor environment they consist of gases and particulates

particulars are the small fine particles of material that float in the air and can be very tiny the ones of greatest interest or about 1/10 of diameter of a human hair they can also be biologically derived and in fact in the indoor environment in most of the instances that we've worked in most serious health problems for people have related to biological constituents being present in the space often mold or bacteria will grow in a space or in the air handling system or in parts of the building where they can then

then be transmitted to people in the spaces these can cause direct illness they can cause all kinds of problems for from a respiratory perspective and there are a wide range of things both biological and chemical that can cause these kinds of problems so indoor are constituents are very diverse and the entire building must be managed properly in order to achieve acceptable levels of those constituents in most indoor environments

several exciting technology developments have taken place over the last few years one of the most exciting is the Improvement in air-to-air heat exchangers and other devices that allow you to take in more outdoor air and ventilate the space more effectively without increasing energy costs that's a very important feature to most building owners in addition these technologies have improved over the last few years so that they can be readily retrofit onto existing equipment that's a

very big Improvement it means that there doesn't need to be a major change in a building to install these devices now one of the great advantages of these new devices is also for hot and humid climates they're able to control humidity from outdoor air this is something that in the past was not available for air-to-air heat exchangers and it was a major problem of increasing humidity levels in buildings in those climates all those factors mean in the long run you can increase ventilation rates very cost-effectively now and that's
tremendous opportunity to improve indoor air quality both in buildings where smoking is allowed or in any building

there are a number of options for the accommodation of non-smokers and smokers in indoor environments the workplace and any other kind of indoor environment those options relate to ventilation you need to have a sufficient amount of outdoor air to dilute the effects of smoking and they relate to issues of whether you have discretionary smoking in the space or whether you separate smokers and non-smokers into different areas when you do any of those activities the first thing

I have to look at is to make sure that everybody gets enough outdoor air because even in a non-smoking environment sufficient ventilation is critical and then in the relationship between smoking and non-smoking environments you want to use things like the pressure relationship that you can create with ventilation systems to isolate the smoking area so that smoke doesn't drift into the non-smoking area this is a very simple procedure but one which can be applied very readily and many many buildings it offers a great deal of flexibility

several of the the really outstanding technology improvements over the last few years have resulted in equipment which can readily be retrofitted to existing Building Systems to package air conditioning units and to existing air Handling Systems so that they take the return air from the system exhaust it but capture the energy value of that system and take an outdoor air precondition it and use it instead that gives you outdoor air ventilation at a very cost effective

active price in addition some filtration technology has evolved over the last few years which allows very inexpensive retrofit to existing equipment and allows the same are to amount of air to be delivered but with very great particulate removal efficiency and much cleaner indoor environment its benefits everybody on the indoor air quality level whether you have smoking in an area or not it's a big Improvement in indoor air quality
the way we've been able to accommodate the mix of smokers and non-smokers is by putting in a special air filtration system

we originally had a problem where a number of my key employees were heavy smokers and obviously this caused a problem between those it smoked and those that didn't and on more than one occasion I try to implement a non-smoking policy which
